February 21, 2017 8:40 am Final reading of Nova Scotia teachers contract underway at Province House By Dave Squires Digital Broadcast Journalist Global News 
The third and final reading of Bill 75 got underway early Tuesday Morning at the Nova Scotia Legislature. Marieke Walsh / Global News What is this?

READ MORE: Nova Scotia to impose parts of contract previously rejected by teachers 
MLAs were met with numerous protesters outside the Nova Scotia legislature as they returned to debate after a three-day break over the past weekend. Teachers and their supporters are rallying in front of @NSLeg now with the aim of convincing gov. to stop #Bill75 . #NSpoli #NSTU #NovaScotia pic.twitter.com/RqS1OSRXXR 
Despite efforts by the opposition to reset the clock on the legislation, Bill 75 is expected to be proclaimed as law once debate wraps up either Tuesday afternoon or evening. NDP amendment accepted 
During the debate early Tuesday morning, the McNeil government accepted an amendment proposed by the NDP, allowing an arbitrator to intervene should members of the Council to Improve Classroom Conditions find themselves at an impasse. That consideration was included in the third tentative agreement voted down by Nova Scotia Teachers Union membership. 
READ MORE: Nova Scotia Liberals reject union’s changes to legislated teachers contract 
No other amendments are expected to be made to the bill. 
Teachers will continue protesting the legislation until the final hour, the union says, and another rally outside Province House is planned to get underway at 3:30 p.m. Tuesday, after school wraps up for the day. 
“It’s crucial that our presence is felt, as MLAs make a decision that will forever impact our education system. I know the rallying that has occurred outside MLA offices over the weekend has helped raise awareness for our cause,” NSTU president Liette Doucet said in a statement. © 2017 Global News, a division of Corus Entertainment Inc.
